Environmental issues pertaining to global warming and pollution have become a global concern and solutions are, therefore, being urgently sought with a wide ranging application of suitable entity to minimize the energy consumption while curbing associated economic costs. Prussian blue (PB) ( Fe 4 3 + [ F e 2 + ( CN ) 6 ] 3 ) and its PB analogous (PBA) ( A 2 T [ M ( CN ) 6 ] , A=Li, K, Na; T=Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, Cu, etc.; M=Fe, Mn, Co, etc.) are metal organic frameworks that have numerous appliances and have garnered major attention in recent years. However, there are only handful of reviews discussing the fundamental catalytic properties of PB-based materials and hence this effort to comprehensively review and systematically discuss the critical role of PB-based materials in broader catalytic context embracing environment and the energy aspects. Initially, the fundamentals and principles of underlying processes are elucidated followed by a detailed discussion on the catalytic performance and applications of PBA-based catalysts in advanced oxidation processes, reduction reactions, water splitting, and miscellaneous applications, among others. This comprehensive overview features details of the broad catalytic activities of PBA-based materials in diverse applications and hopefully would be a reference on PBA-centered catalysts in an array of applications including industrial applications. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Prussian blue Metal organic framework Hexacyanoferrate Catalysis Coordination polymer Nanocatalyst 1 Introduction Due to the rapid growth of industrialization around the world, environmental issues such as global warming, air, soil, and water pollution have become an overwhelming problem and have attracted a global attention. Thus, several studies have been undertaken to overcome these global issues such as specific focus on renewable energy technologies like solar power, wind power, and biogas production to decrease the effect of global warming. In addition, advanced oxidation treatments have been developed to treat water, soil and air contamination leading to the fabrication and utilization of many materials and chemicals to conduct these methods. However, due to energy consumption involved and the economic constraints, the search for such ideal multipurpose materials with a broad range of applications is imperative; metal organic frameworks (MOFs) are such class of materials with various applications [1,2]. MOFs, with three dimensional crystalline and porous networks comprising metal ions and organic ligands, have been used in several industrial applications due to their unique structure and properties; most common appliances being in gas storage and broad-based catalytic activities [2]. The prominent characteristic of MOFs is porosity which is reminiscent of features represented by zeolites although their advantages outweigh zeolites [3]. Moreover, MOFs have displayed great persistence in microporosity after solvent evacuation [4]. Prussian blue (PB), termed ferric ferrocyanide, is a polynuclear complex including transition metal (Fe) and cyanide group (CN) and as a MOF have had industrial applications since 18th century, being considered as the first synthetic pigment discovered in textile industry [5] with initial structural forms discovered in 1936 by Keggin and Miles [6]. Their proposed form showed that PB comprise iron ions including ferrous (Fe2+) and ferric (Fe3+) located at the corners of a cube which is linked by cyanide ligands with the general formula of Fe 4 3 + [ F e 2 + ( CN ) 6 ] 3 ; their assembly can be achieved by mixing ferric or ferrous with hexacyanoferrate ions and different oxidation states of iron [7]. Since the advent of PB, extensive attempts have been made to synthesize other compounds by substituting iron with other transition metals like Ni, Cu, Co, and Mn. This has led to creation of PB analogues (PBA) with general formula of A x T [ M ( CN ) 6 ] . n H 2 O where A represents an alkaline ion (Li, Na, K), T represents transition metals (Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, Zn, Cu, Mg), and M also represents transition metals (Fe, Mn, Co) [1]. These larger varieties of assorted PBA's have made them useful materials with a wide-ranging application in diverse fields such as energy storage, sensors, medicine, and catalysis, among others [8–13]. It is worth mentioning that the alkaline ions can be extracted or intercalated making PBA a good cathode material for ion batteries; they can be deployed for hydrogen storage [1]. The presence of transition metals has made PBA a suitable class of catalysts in varied applications namely oxygen evolution and hydrogen evolution reactions [14–16]. Although PB and PBA have a long history in industrial applications, new state-of-the-art applications have recently been emerged, as they have been used in environmental applications for decontamination purposes. Fig. 1 depicts the broad catalytic application of PB-based nanomaterials in different disciplines based on the publications since 1986. In addition, several synthesis methods have been documented including coprecipitation, hydrothermal methods, and electrodeposition. As shown in Fig. 2 , the scientific community have embraced PB-based catalysts enthusiastically in recent years as illustrated by dramatic increase in the number of published papers since 2017. However, the number of review papers on the subject matter, that can be a keystone for future studies, is rather limited and is only 2.8% of the papers published on PB and its analogous (Fig. 3 ); to the best of our knowledge there is not a review paper comprehensively discussing the catalytic applications of PB and its analogues. Therefore, this review aims to provide an extensive overview of catalytic applications of PB-based materials. In this regard, first, chemical and structural properties are discussed followed by their catalytic applications in diverse fields and finally, the future perspective and challenges are deliberated. 2 Properties of PB and its analogues 2.1 Structural properties PB with the formula of Fe 4 3 + [ F e 2 + ( CN ) 6 ] 3 . x H 2 O is a poly-nuclear complex with a 3D cubic structure comprising ferrous and ferric ions located at the corners of cube and linked with a cyanide ligand [1]; FeII is linked with carbon while the FeIII is connected with nitrogen. Insoluble and soluble PB are the two main types that can be formed by the conventional co-precipitation synthesis method; insoluble PB ensues when the material has surplus FeIII instead of alkali metal while soluble form has alkali metals [17]. In the regard to PB analogues (PBA), the formula is A x T [ M ( CN ) 6 ] . n H 2 O where A corresponds to Li, Na, K while T and M correspond to Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, Zn, Cu, Mg, etc.; the structures of PB and its analogous are illustrated in Fig. 4 [18]. Like PB, the transition metal at N presents the high-spin state and the atom at C presents the low-spin state. In PBA, the cyanide group acts as a bridge to connect the two transition metals. One attractive aspect of PBA is that the two transition metals can have different oxidation states while keeping the cubic structure unchanged [1,5]. PBA has a cubic structure that relies on alkaline ions because these ions can change their shape to monoclinic or rhombohedral crystal as depicted in Fig. 5 [19]. Additionally, the structure of PB and PBA can be modified using acid or alkaline solutions [20]. For example, Hu et al. [21] revealed that by using HCl, hollow PB particles could be attained. In addition, Zhang et al. [22] mixed PB with NaOH solution to synthesis Fe(OH)3 microcubes. The synthesis methods are performed in aqueous solutions and thus, PBA contains water either on its surface or in the structure. The water in the framework includes the zeolitic water corresponded with inner sites where the water is chemically bound with the M atoms [1]. The adsorbed water on the surface and the zeolitic water can be removed since they are physically adsorbed while the M ion coordinated water cannot be detached easily due to its chemical bonding with the metal ion [23]. In addition, crystals’ size was found to be important for the water adsorption's strength [24]. 2.2 Chemical properties Given that PBA contains metal ions, this material is capable of cation exchange [25], a phenomenon that facilitates the preparation of hollow nanoparticles. Using this property, researchers have been able to replace cations in the structure of the PBA to synthesize new materials and composites. For example, when Mn-Fe PBA introduced into a solution of Co or Ni, the Mn can be replaced by cobalt or nickel ions, this process may lead to core-shell structures. If more Fe ions react with the new metal ions, it may result in a hollow structure [26]. In addition to cation exchange, anions can be exchanged in PBAs; anion exchange capability also produces different structures. For instance, if a Ni-Co PBA is mixed with Na2S, a NiS nanoframe will be produced. Since the edges of the PBA are more reactive than its surfaces, they can be etched [27]. As the process progresses, a nanoframe with hollow core will be produced. In this context, PBA can be used as a precursor to prepare sulfides and selenides of metals. Additionally, alkaline ions can be introduced into the PBA since the two transition metals in PBA formula are capable of electrochemical properties [28]. 3 Catalytic applications 3.1 Persulfate activation Degradation of pollutants by sulfate radicals is one of the prominent advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) that have been studied extensively [29,30]. Oxidation potential of SO 4 • − radical is 2.5–3.1 V vs. NHE while OH· radical's potential is 1.8–2.7 V vs. NHE. Nonetheless, generation of sulfate radicals is slow that makes it relatively less favorable than OH· [31]. Many studies have indicated that transition metals (Co, Ni, Mn, Fe, Ag, and Cu, etc) are the preeminent catalysts to activate potassium peroxymonosulfate (PMS) for the generation of sulfate radicals [32,33]. MOFs have been examined [34] for their catalytic activities in environmental applications [34] in view of their stable structure and configuration which renders them suitable catalyst. Several studies evaluated PBA's catalytic performance derived from different metal species like Fe, Co, Cu, Mn, and Ni [35–37]. Table 1 presents a comparison of PBA-based catalysts in the activation of PMS. For example, Lin et al. [38] investigated [Fe(CN)6] and [Co(CN)6]-centered PBAs using five transition metals (Fe, Co, Cu, Mn, Ni). Ni, and Cu); Fe containing PBAs lacked performance whereas Mn and Co-based PBA were found to activate PMS noticeably. However, the degradation rate and kinetics of Co-Co and Co-Fe PBAs were higher and faster than Mn-Co and Mn-Fe indicating the important role of M2+ (metal ion) in PMS activation. The results clearly demonstrated that the degradation process could be attributed to PBA particles rather than the leached metal ions in the solution since the concentration of metal ions was lower when PBA was added to the solution. Eq. (1) shows the general PMS activation by metal species [39]. (1) M n + + HSO 5 − → M ( n + 1 ) + SO 4 • − + O H − In bimetallic compounds like iron/cobalt-based PBAs, since the redox potential of cobalt is higher than iron, cobalt can be reduced by iron via Eq. (2). This transformation can persistently activate PMS to generate reactive radicals [37,40]. (2) F e 2 + + C o 3 + → F e 3 + + C o 2 + Although the metallic catalysts were found to be effective for activating PMS, their agglomeration during pyrolysis impedes their effectiveness. Therefore, several studies have investigated the addition of carbonaceous materials like graphene, carbon nanotubes, and graphitized nanodiamonds to the metallic catalyst; carbonaceous materials not only prevented the catalyst from agglomeration but catalyzed the PMS activation [41–45]. In addition to agglomeration, conventional fabrication of metallic nanoparticles and carbon-based materials is laborious and sophisticated. Therefore, recent studies have explored the application of PBAs as a precursor for preparation of the metallic/carbon nanocomposites because they can retain its structure and morphologies during high temperature manipulations resulting in its direct transformation into carbon-based frameworks. Consequently, the integration of carbon and PBA leads to larger surface areas and greater pores in the composite [46–48]. Carbon sites are activated by functional groups, heteroatom dopants, and defects or edges which renders the sp2 carbon network active in catalytic reactions. Moreover, it has been revealed that carbon-based catalysts not only outperformed metallic catalysts but also had lower toxicity and higher stability under acidic or basic conditions [49,50]. Recent studies have shown that the encapsulation of metal nanoparticles into carbonaceous structure can enhance the catalytic performance due to the optimized functionality, electron configuration, and the electron density of states on the exterior carbon lattice at Fermi level. Additionally, iron and carbon-based composites imparted magnetic properties to the catalyst which facilitated the recovery procedure [51–53]. Furthermore, if heteroatoms such as nitrogen and sulfur are doped with the carbonaceous material, the synergistic effect come into play; nitrogen-doped catalysts could activate PMS through non-radical oxidation process in which graphitic nitrogen atoms were the active sites. The graphitic N atoms facilitate the charge transfer from carbon to nitrogen by breaking the inertness of sp2 carbon configuration thus generating positively charged sites on the carbon surface resulting in improved PMS adsorption [54–57]. A possible activation mechanism through heteroatoms is shown in Fig. 6 . Liu et al. [51] reported that the π-electrons in sp2 of carbon network can be activated via electrons of heteroatoms to activated PMS; sp2 hybridized carbon can be transferred to PMS to generate sulfate radicals wherein C=O groups played a crucial role in PMS activation as a result of nucleophilic attack. Duan et al. [58] investigated the catalytic performance of cobalt-carbon PBA composite in the activation of PMS. The catalytic activity is based on the PMS adsorption, electron transfer and cleavage of peroxide O–O bond of PMS. They revealed that doping nitrogen into graphene, in addition to using PBA as cobalt precursor, could enhance the catalytic performance of the composite. It was discovered that the cobalt/graphene structure led to a heterostructure, enhancing the adsorption energy of PMS on the carbon surface which generated more free radicals due to the cleavage of O-O bond and the enhanced electron transfer. Li et al. [59] disclosed that with composite derived from PBA and carbon, the degradation of the target contaminant was facilitated so that the pollutant was eliminated completely in 30 min; Eq. (3) to (5) show how metal species [M] on metallic/carbon composites can react with the PMS to generate free radicals. (3) M 0 → M 2 + + 2 e − (4) M 2 + + HSO 5 − → M 3 + + SO 4 • − + O H − (5) M 3 + + HSO 5 − → M 2 + + SO 5 • − + H + Then, the produced SO 5 • − further evolved to 2 SO 4 • − through Eq. (6). Moreover, the sulfate radicals can be transformed into O H • via Eq. (7) via hydrolysis. These higher amounts of free radicals can degrade PBA into CO2 and other degradation products. (6) 2 SO 5 • − → 2 SO 4 • − + O 2 (7) SO 4 • − + H 2 O → SO 4 2 − + O H • + H + Additionally, it was shown that PBA could create more pores and greater surface area in the composite which leads to the higher adsorption and catalytic activity. A number of studies have shown that integration of PBA with S/N doped carbon facilitated the electron transfer in carbon materials, dispersion of metallic species, and provided access to active sites due to the six cyanide groups in the PBA that enhanced the N/C ratio in the composite, thus improving the non-radical activation pathway [54,56,59]. In addition to conventional activation methods, photocatalytic activation of PMS has been studied. Guo et al. [60] investigated the photocatalytic activation of PMS using carbon-based Cu-Fe oxide composite under ultraviolet-visible light; excellent efficiency in activation and reusability of the catalyst was discerned with plausible reaction mechanisms (Fig. 7 ). Fe and Cu atoms activated PMS to generate SO 4 • − and SO 5 • − radicals. In addition, Cu(II) can be transferred to Cu(I) via light irradiation. The composite comprising CuFe2O4, CuO, and C expediated the charge transfer under the light irradiation wherein the photo-induced electron attacked the peroxy bond of PMS to generate reactive species. Numerous studies have investigated the effects of varying shapes and configurations of PBA such as core-shell, spiderweb-like, concave, polygonal cubes, nanocage and nanosheet-like on the removal of contaminants and their catalytic performances [40,61–65]; schematics of morphologies Evaluated by Zhang et al. [40] namely concave, polygonal cubes, and core-shell configurations of Fe/Co PBA are depicted in Fig. 8 . Apparently, the core-shell morphology had better performance since it facilitated the Fe and Co synergism along with its larger surface area which promoted more active sites. Another main goal to change the configuration of PBA-based catalysts is to prevent the metals from leaching out of the catalysts. In this regard, studies have been performed to cover the surface of the PBA as exemplified by Zeng et al. [62] as they synthesized a core-shell PBA coated by poly(m-phenylenediamine) (PmPD). The results revealed that the composite not only was capable of activating PMS but also inhibited the leaching of Co where its concentration was reduced by 50% in the solution; PmPD has sufficient amino groups protecting the metallic core from leaching ions via interaction of Co ions with the layer. A reaction mechanism has also been proposed by the authors Fig. 9 ); reactions being the same as in Eq. (4) to ((6). 3.2 Fenton-based reactions Among AOPs, Fenton-based techniques like photo-Fenton and electro-Fenton have been broadly studied, typical Fenton reactions are defined in Eq. (8) and (9) [66]. The main issue with the Fenton process is that the kinetics of Eq. (9) is slower leading to the accumulation of ferric ions. Consequently, several explorations have been conducted to boost the Fenton reactions via catalysts [67,68]. (8) F e 2 + + H 2 O 2 → F e 3 + + H O • + O H − (9) F e 3 + + H 2 O 2 → F e 2 + + HO 2 • + H + There are multiple reports on the deployment of metals other than iron to oxidize H2O2 [69,70]. However, the leaching of metals into the solution would cause biotoxicity [71]. Therefore, a robust support to accommodate catalysts is warranted to prevent the metal leaching. Due to its structural features and Fe atoms, PB has attracted a lot of attentions in this context recently. Moreover, PB was recognized to have the same selectivity and catalytic activity as the peroxidase enzyme for hydrogen peroxide. Since the kinetics of the Fenton reactions is slow, introduction of reducing agents to the catalysts was tested to accelerate the cycle of Fe2+/Fe3+ [72–75]. For example, Li et al. [75] developed Fe3+-Co PBA catalysts enriched with hydrazine (Hz) as a reducing agent to enhance the oxidation capability of the catalyst; addition of Hz could reduce ferric ions to ferrous ions and it was affirmed that hydrazine indeed could replace water in PBA's structure to facilitate the oxidation of H2O2. The proposed mechanism for the promoted process is represented by Eq. (10) to (14). First, Hz replaced water and created a hydrazine coordinated site and as a result the Fe3+ content in FeN6 increased Eq. (10)). Then, the new coordinated site could produce HOO• radicals through Eq. (11) and ((12) since the [ Fe ( CN ) 5 ( Hz ) ] 2 − performed as an active site. Additionally, ferrous produced in [Fe(CN)5(H2O)]3− would be oxidized to [Fe(CN)5(H2O)]2− resulting in the generation of hydroxyl radicals’ (Eq.(13) and (14)). (10) [ Fe ( CN ) 5 ( H 2 O ) ] 2 − + Hz → [ Fe ( CN ) 5 ( Hz ) ] 2 − + H 2 O (11) [ Fe ( CN ) 5 ( Hz ) ] 2 − + H 2 O 2 → [ Fe ( CN ) 5 ( H 2 O 2 ) ] 2 − + Hz (12) [ F e ( C N ) 5 ( H 2 O 2 ) ] 2 − → [ F e ( C N ) 5 ( H 2 O ) ] 2 − + H O O • + H + (13) [ F e ( C N ) 5 ( H 2 O ) ] 3 − + H 2 O 2 → [ F e ( C N ) 5 ( H 2 O 2 ) ] 3 − + H 2 O (14) [ F e ( C N ) 5 ( H 2 O 2 ) ] 3 − → [ F e ( C N ) 5 ( H 2 O ) ] 3 − + H O • + O H − Thus, the addition of a reducing agent could enhance the homogeneous Fenton reaction through promoted dissolution of Fe3+-Co PBA. Besides, recent studies have tried to develop PBA composites and a support like membranes and cerium oxide [76,77]. For instance, Lin et al. [77] prepared a composite of PBA on a polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) membrane which increased the porosity to capture more pollutants and accommodate additional PBA as the precursor of Fenton reagent. Based on the results, the carbon coordinated iron (Fe2+) and nitrogen coordinated iron (Fe3+) would be oxidized to Fe3+ and Fe2+ through Eq. (8) and Eq. (9), respectively. The generated •OOH would further react with hydrogen peroxide to generate hydroxyl radicals via Eq. (15); plausible reaction mechanism is depicted in Fig. 10 . (15) H O O • + H 2 O 2 → O H • + H 2 O + O 2 Cerium oxide (CeO2) has been studied widely as a catalyst support in view of its redox potential and oxygen vacancies (OVs) that facilitates the adsorption of H2O2 easier [78–80] as shown by Zhang et al. [76] in the synthesis of a CeO2-modified PB composite for its catalytic prowess. The results indicated that addition of CeO2 increased active sites and oxygen storage/release capacity due to the redox shift between Ce4+ and Ce3+. In addition, they reported that with the increase in PB content of composite, the catalytic performance was enhanced on the grounds that: 1) the iron content in the composite was increased; 2) doping of PB and cerium oxide could cause structural deformation resulting in production of OVs which are reportedly known to be effective in the reduction of H2O2 to OH• and acceleration of electron transfer between Fe2+ to Fe3+; 3) the synergistic effect of Fe and Ce facilitated the electron transfer between Ce and Fe ions. The proposed reaction pathway is represented in Eq. (16) and (17) showing that the PB was capable of catalyzing hydrogen peroxide to produce reactive radicals. (16) [ F e ( C N ) 6 ( H 2 O ) ] 3 − + H 2 O 2 → [ F e ( C N ) 6 ( H 2 O ) ] 4 − + H O O • + H + (17) [ F e ( C N ) 6 ( H 2 O ) ] 4 − + H 2 O 2 → [ F e ( C N ) 6 ( H 2 O ) ] 3 − + H O • + O H − The structural modification is another way to tune PB-based catalysts to change their surface channels and atomic structure using various means including chemical etching, coordination modulation, and reverse microemulsion [81–83]. Liu et al. [84] prepared four different morphologies of Fe-Co PBA including sphere, truncated sphere, truncated cube, and cubic structure using polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) at varying temperatures ranging from 0 to 85 °C. They revealed that in Fenton reactions the content of Fe2+ and specific surface area were the two important factors. It could be concluded from the results that the (100) facet played a key role in the Fenton process since the H2O2 adsorption was much higher than (110) and (111) surfaces leading to generation of higher amount of OH• radicals. Thus, cubic structure had stronger surface energy and showed better catalytic performance in comparison to other morphologies. Regarding the active species affecting the degradation process, it was found that singlet oxygen is the active species mostly affecting the Fenton process. In photo-Fenton reactions, the conventional Fenton process is accompanied by a light source. Thus, the generation of OH• would be facilitated by reduction of ferric ions (in the form of Fe(OH)2+) and photolysis of H2O2 through Eq. (18) to (20) [85]. Basically, in addition to decomposition of hydrogen peroxide, there are two main mechanisms affecting the catalytic performance of the PBA. First, the presence of iron ions on PBA's surface which catalyze H2O2 to generate OH•. Second, H2O2 enhances the adsorption of photo-induced electrons to generate OH• [86,87]. [88] developed two different Fe-Co PBA catalysts based on FeII and FeIII where FeII was oxidized by H2O2 to form Fe-O phase (iron oxide and/or hydroxide) at a faster rate while FeIII was reduced at a slower rate. Despite of the slower kinetics, the FeIII-Co PBA showed noticeable stability (in terms of metal leaching) in comparison to FeII-Co PBA. The high catalytic performance of the two catalysts was attributed to the presence of water coordinated iron atoms and the porosity of the PBA; possible mechanistic pathway for the photo-Fenton reaction follows Eq. (21) and (22). First, the water molecules were replaced by H2O2 and then the iron-peroxide complex will further react with water to produce hydroxyl radicals. Similarly, superoxide radicals would be produced by the reduction of Fe3+-Co PBA by H2O2. (21) [ F e ( C N ) 5 ( H 2 O ) ] 3 − + H 2 O 2 → [ F e ( C N ) 5 ( H 2 O 2 ) ] 3 − + H 2 O → [ F e ( C N ) 5 ( H 2 O ) ] 3 − + H O • + O H − (22) [ F e ( C N ) 5 ( H 2 O ) ] 2 − + H 2 O 2 → [ F e ( C N ) 5 ( H 2 O 2 ) ] 2 − + H 2 O → [ F e ( C N ) 5 ( H 2 O ) ] 3 − + H O O • + H + The unique structure of PB has prompted researchers to investigate various morphologies or sizes of PBA composites in different processes like photo-Fenton [89,90]. Wang et al. [89] investigated the catalytic performance of a series of PB catalysts including cubes, cubes with truncated corners, cubes with truncated edges, cubes with protrusive faces, hexapods, and hexapod shown in Fig. 11 . They reported that hexapods and hexapod stars outperformed the cubic morphologies. The superior performance of hexapods can possibly be explained by the theory of hard and soft acids where Fe3+ and Fe2+ are hard and borderline acids, respectively. Theoretically, hard acids tend to bind to hard bases while soft acids bind to soft bases. In this regard, the connection of Fe2+ with CN which is a soft base is much stronger than the connection of Fe3+ with CN. This difference in the bond strength makes the Fe2+-CN bond less reactive for the activation of H2O2. Hence, hexapod-based catalysts with lower Fe2+-CN bonds displayed better catalytic activity. Furthermore, the morphological studies showed that the etching process caused more Fe3+ sites. Additionally, the content of Fe3+-O was larger in hexapod-based catalysts indicating that oxygen containing groups like OH− can provide the charge balance. In view of the abovementioned theory and studies, the Fe3+/Fe2+ ratio plays an important role on the catalytic performance as hexapod-based PBs benefited from higher ratio. Since PB can accommodate different transition metals, varying combinations of transition metals of PBA have been used as precursors to develop Fenton-like catalysts as shown by Cheng et al. [91] by preparing Cu-Fe oxide (CuFeO) catalyst derived from PBA for photo-Fenton process. They reported that CuFeO surpassed the pristine Cu-Fe PBA in performance as the CuFeO had better porous structure with more abundant metals; oxidation of copper is like iron in Fenton reaction as represented by Eq. (23) and (24). The mechanistic study Fig. 12 ) revealed that Cu2O was generated on the surface of the catalyst indicating the presence of Cu(I) which is known as a hydrogen peroxide decomposer. Furthermore, the presence of light could excite Fe3O4 and CuO in the catalyst resulting in the generation of H+ and e− via Eq. (25) and ((26). Based on the radical scavenger's test, the role of e− was found more critical because it can facilitate the production of OH• (Eq. (27)) and reduction of Cu2+ and Fe3+ to Cu+ and Fe2+, respectively. Besides, the Cu+ can reduce Fe3+ to Fe2+ via Eq. (28) thus enhancing the catalytic performance. [98] evaluated the performance of a chainmail catalyst comprising oxidized carbon nanotube (OCNT) and Fe-Co PBA on the electro-Fenton process. The synthesized material was used as a working and counter electrode along with a Pt plate. The ratio of OCNT/PBA is one key parameter affecting the performance of the composite. In view of that, excess PBA content hindered attaining chainmail structure as the material lacked the electron transporter. On the other hand, excess amount of OCNT could cause aggregation on the PBA's surface. Based on the results obtained, proposed mechanisms are shown in Fig. 13 . Firstly, OCNT causes the generation of hydrogen peroxide on the surface of PBA which then will be oxidized to singlet oxygen for further degradation; (100) facet played an essential role in the production of 1O2. To shed light on the proposition, it should be noted that OH• , a product of H2O2 oxidation, detaches from (100) facet because of weak adsorption and undergoes reaction with H O 2 • to form 1O2. Secondly, OCNT acted as a bridge to facilitate electron transfer between cathode and iron species in PBA. Thirdly, iron ions and oxygen containing groups will create COO-Fe complexes that would serve as a mediator to change iron's spin states and facilitates the Fe2+/Fe3+ cycles. This happens on the grounds that ORR sites are in proximity to Fenton catalyst resulting in superior diffusion of H2O2 and reduction of Fe3+. 3.3 Photocatalytic degradation Photocatalytic degradation has been well developed and is classified as an environmentally friendly AOPs since 70s [99,100] wherein a photocatalyst which is usually a semiconductor harnesses energy from a light source to produce reactive species for the degradation of pollutants. When photons hit the surface of the semiconductor, free electrons (e−) and positive holes (h+) are generated in the conduction band (CB) and valance band (VB), respectively. The free electrons and positive holes will give rise to the generation of reactive species through Eq. (32) and (33) [101]. (32) e − + O 2 → • O 2 − (33) h + + H 2 O → H + + O H • Generally, the removal process in photocatalytic reactions consists of adsorption of the pollutant on the surface of the catalysts and followed by its degradation via the generation of active species. The adsorption step depends on mass transfer, adsorbent resistance, diffusion and binding of particles with the surface while the degradation step revolves around adsorption of pollutant, absorption of light, and the charge transfer [102,103]. The photocatalytic activity of the catalysts depends on the supply of electrons and holes along with prevention of their recombination. In view of this, coupling p-type (pure) with n-type (impure) semiconductors can reduce the recombination because of the formation of type-II band alignment which makes the generated electrons and holes to transfer in an opposite direction [104]. Given that, usually zero valent iron, iron oxide zinc oxide, and TiO2 nanoparticles have been used to prepare photocatalysts for the degradation of pollutants [105,106]. Metal hexacyanoferrates (MHCFs) or PBAs have been studied recently in photocatalytic experiments due to their semiconducting features and narrow band gap [107–109]. Table 2 presents different PBA-based catalysts deployed in photocatalytic degradation with their associated band gaps. Among MHCFs, Zn-based HCFs have been investigated extensively since PB can be used as the precursor for ZnFe2O4 which has been proven to have photocatalytic activity [110]. As an example, Cao et al. [111] developed a porous ZnFe2O4 nanocubes from PBA wherein the hollow structure improved the dispersion of light through the catalysts making electrons and holes in VB and CB, respectively. It was concluded that OH• can be generated through the process other than Eq. (33). Initially, the • O 2 − would react with H+ to produce •OOH (Eq. (34)) and then it reacts with H+ and e− to produce OH• (Eq. (35)). (34) • O 2 − + H + → • O O H (35) • O O H + H + + 2 e − → O H • + 2 O H − In addition, ZnFe2O4, and ZnO have been widely investigated as dopants in photocatalytic studies due to their stability, narrow band gap, and biocompatibility. Incorporation of zinc oxide into PBA's structure can reduce the band gap and enhance the photocatalytic activity of the composite [112,113]. Rachna et al. [113] evaluated the performance of ZnO-PBA nanocomposite in photocatalysis of bisphenol A and nonylphenol. The accommodation of ZnO on to the PBA's lattice decreased the energy band gap of pristine ZnO (3.3 eV) and PBA (1.2 eV) to 1.1 eV. The photoluminescence spectra are linked with the photocatalytic activity. The low intensity in the spectra for the prepared catalysts showed that the recombination was significantly quenched due to the encapsulation of PBA by ZnO in which ZnO separated the charges. Several studies have also investigated the doping of Zn-based catalysts with other metals. For instance, Wu et al. [114] evaluated the performance of Ag/ZnO/ZnFe2O4 nanocomposite. Incorporation of Ag into the structure enhanced the light absorption capacity probably because the Ag particles could improve the absorption of plasmon resonance. Besides, the modification of zinc composite with silver instigated the formation of Schottky barrier between zinc oxide and silver along with the formation of type-II band alignment leading to lower recombination. As shown in Fig. 14 a, as the Fermi energy levels of these materials are different, electrons will be kept transferring until the modified zinc composite's Fermi energy level reaches an equilibrium with the Ag's. It is noteworthy that because the Fermi energy level of ZnO is higher than the equilibrium state's energy level, generated electrons will be accumulated in silver by oxygen resulting in the formation of superoxide radicals. Subsequently, the recombination will be decreased by the introduction of silver to the composite. Additionally, the authors reported that options other than incorporation of Ag, the structure of the synthesized nanocomposite could affect the catalytic activity. Given different structures, the hollow composite showed better efficiency in the removal of the targeted pollutant rather than porous composite. This enhanced catalytic activity was ascribed to the synergistic effects between the structure and the larger surface area of the composite which could promote the charge transfer. Other transition metals hexacyanoferrates (HCFs) have been evaluated in photocatalysis. For example, Rachna et al. [115] incorporated zinc oxide into the Cu-PB's structure using Azadirachta indica extract for the green synthesis of the composite; the ensuing ZnO-Cu nanocomposite benefited from the synergistic effect of zinc and copper. It was reported that the CuHCF paved the way of the adsorption of the contaminant for the subsequent degradation process. In addition, the lower photoluminescence intensity of the composite proved the superior catalytic activity of the composite. Since the band gap energy of Cu-PB (1.9 eV) is lower than ZnO (3.3 eV), electrons will be transferred from Cu-PB to ZnO after excitation leading to the formation of oxidative species via redox reactions mentioned above Eq. (32) to ((34)) which are further illustrated in Fig. 14b. In another study, Rani et al. [116] evaluated the photocatalytic performance of four different HCFs using Zn, Cu, Co, and Ni; the degradation efficacy of the composites being in the order: Zn > Cu> Ni > Co and was attributed to higher zeta potential and larger surface area of the zinc hexacyanoferrate's structure. The higher zeta potential indicated stronger repellency that reduces the risk of aggregation. Higher surface area also revealed that the ZnHCF had better ability for adsorption of more pollutants that results in the higher removal efficiency. In another work, Rani et al. [117] investigated the catalytic activities of Cd and Mn-based PBA in the removal of organic dyes. Although both metals showed noticeable performance, cadmium had better performance since its zeta potential and surface area were higher and larger than the manganese nanocomposite. Cesium removal via deposition of TiO2 on PB is yet another catalytic application of PB. It was reported that the hydration radius of Cs is similar to the PB's lattice spacing thus increasing the adsorption ability of PB. In addition, Cs can bind to hydrophilic sites of PB through proton elimination of the coordination water [118–120]. Previously, it was reported that iron species in PB can be reduced by the photo-induced electron to form a colorless material called Prussian white (PW) (Eq. (36)). Based on Keggin and Miles structural model, PB has one alkali metal while PW has two alkali metals [121]; structures for PB and PW are depicted in Fig. 15 a. In another study, Park et al. [122] reported that deposition of TiO2 on the surface of PB could increase the adsorption ability of PB; a simultaneous reduction of PB and enhancement of Cs adsorption was observed. Fig. 15b proposes the underlying removal mechanism for Cs through TiO2/PB composite. According to the Fig. 15b, when the light is present, the photo-induced electrons reduce Fe3+ to Fe2+ making the composite a great adsorbent for cesium. (36) P B [ F e ( I I I ) − C N − F e ( I I ) ] + e − → P W [ F e ( I I ) − C N − F e ( I I ) ] 3.4 Reduction reactions In contrast to oxidation reactions, in reduction reactions the compound of interest gains electron and gets reduced. Among important reductants in different applications, iron species have garnered a lot of attention [123]. In this context, PB and its analogues have been used extensively in diverse reduction reactions namelythe reduction of pollutants like nitroaromatics and NOX, and hydrogen peroxide reduction [124–126]. Aromatic nitro group (ArNO2) are present in many industrial products like pesticides, dyes, and explosives. Eq. (37) shows a series of typical reduction reactions of aromatic nitro groups. The major final products are amino compounds while nitroso (II) and hydroxylamine (III) compounds are the intermediate products in the reduction of nitroaromatics. In reduction reactions, the catalyst accelerates the generation of hydrogen. Then, nitro group and H2 would be adsorbed on the PBA's surface. Eventually, the nitro group will be transferred to amine group through the hydrogenation process [123]. (37) ( I ) A r N O 2 → + 2 e − + 2 H + − H 2 O ( I I ) A r N O → + 2 e − + 2 H + ( I I I ) A r N H O H → + 2 e − + 2 H + − H 2 O ( I V ) A r N H 2 Noble metals such as Ru, Pd, Ag, and Au have been extensively used as catalyst to accelerate the reduction of nitroaromatics [127]. Although noble metals create sites for hydrogenation reactions during their catalytic performance, their cost and sophisticated synthesis have persuaded scientists to develop new catalysts from non-noble metals. In this respect, PBA due to its structure and source of transition metals have attracted researchers. The activation energy is a parameter indicating the efficiency of the catalyst; lower the activation energy, the better the catalyst is. Table 3 compares different key parameters of the PBA-based catalysts like activation energies. 4-Nitrophenol (4-NP) is one of the most common nitroaromatic model pollutants which has been the subject matter of several studies and often, NaBH4 is used as a reducing agent. However, the reaction is extremely slow in the absence of a catalyst as studies have revealed that sodium borohydride could not hydrogenate 4-NP to 4-aminophenol (4-AP) alone [128]. In contrast, when a PBA-based catalyst was added to the solution not only the kinetics but also the efficiency of the reduction process was enhanced. The improved performance is attributed to the synergistic effect of the transition metals like Fe and Co in PBA. Moreover, it was reported that the shape of the synthesized catalysts can affect the catalytic performance [129]. For example, Feng et al. [130] showed that if Co-Fe nano cubes are assembled into micro cuboids, electron transfer may be facilitated since the aggregation issue of the nano cubes will be resolved. Since there are multiple transition metals that can be incorporated into PB, the effect of each metal is of importance. In a study, Wi-Afedzi et al. [131] investigated the effect of Co, Fe, Mn, Ni, and Zn on the reduction of 4-NP; Co-Fe and Ni-Fe were found to be more effective in comparison to Fe-Fe, Mn-Fe, and Zn-Fe. Since NaBH4 is used as the hydrogen source in the reduction reactions, the ability of the Co-Fe and Ni-Fe catalysts in acquiring hydrogen via the decomposition of NaBH4 was much faster than other catalysts. Furthermore, higher surface area of cobalt and nickel-based catalysts provided more active sites for the catalytic performance. Nonetheless, the Co-Fe catalyst was found to provide higher hydrogenation activity than Ni-Fe catalyst. Fig. 16 illustrates the steps of 4-NP reduction involving hydrolysis of NaBH4, reduction reaction, and the desorption of reduced products. A few studies investigated assorted materials such as carbonaceous entities, ion exchange resins, cellulose fibers, and alginate beads to support PBA-based catalysts for reduction reactions. Hu et al. [132] coated a N-doped graphene layer on the surface of Fe-Co PBA, which in addition to synergistic effect of Fe and Co, facilitated the adsorption of 4-NP due to its porosity and nitrogen atoms. Incorporation of nitrogen into carbonaceous materials beside oxygen can provide highly positive sites on the surface as a consequence of their high electronegativity. Therefore, the negatively charged nitro groups can bind with the surface rapidly and easily, thus, accelerating the reduction reaction. Ion exchange resins are other supports that can be deployed to synthesize PBA-based catalysts as they provide an electrostatic surface on which PBA can link, and the spherical shape allows the formation of a homogeneous layer of PBA on the resin's surface. Another reason that these resins are suitable support is their reusability aspect as they afford a facile separation from aqueous solutions making them operational in the industry. Wu et al. [133] fabricated ion exchange resin-PBA catalyst for the reduction of 4-NP when the H2 generation increased dramatically for the hydrogenation process upon addition of catalyst to the solution. The utility of PBA as a support for noble metals is on the rise recently [134,135], especially noble metals like Au and Pd that serve as a mediator to transfer electron from sodium borohydride to PBA; the conductivity of PBA does facilitate the transfer of electrons. As NaBH4 produces H2, because of the nucleophilicity of sodium borohydride, Au/Pd-H bond would be formed. Subsequently, the electron will be transferred to a nitroaromatic compound to be reduced [134]. Since the cyanide groups impede the electron transfer in the structure of PB, insertion of a noble metal circumvents this issue. For instance, Zhang et al. [135] demonstrated that addition of Pd to PBA can change the peaks of cyanide groups in Fourier transform infrared graph (FT-IR) indicating an interaction between Pd and cyanide groups; Pd-PBA catalysts could reduce 4-NP up to 98% including high catalytic activity towards nitroaromatics with other functional groups such as -NH2, -Br, -Cl, -CH3, and -OH. Fig. 17 a depicts the original pathway of electron transfer through NaBH4 while Fig. 17b shows the enhanced electron transfer pathways in the presence of Pd that entails, i: NaBH4 to PBA to nitroaromatics, ii: NaBH4 to Pd to nitroaromatics; iii: NaBH4 to Pd to PBA to nitroaromatics; and iv: NaBH4 to PBA to Pd to nitroaromatics). PBA-based nanocomposites also can be deployed to detect nitroaromatics in the environment as has been illustrated by a study conducted by Wang et al. [136] where PBAs cubes were grown on glucose-derived porous carbon for the ultrasensitive detection of nitroaromatics. A novel one-pot pyrolysis process was used, and in so doing, the efficacy of the pre-adsorption, the rate of electron transfers as well as the electrocatalysis activity of nitroaromatic compounds (NACs) were bolstered; this advanced approach provided the system with a broader range of NAC's detection (1-1000 ppb). Besides, the abovementioned sensors demonstrated other merits, among which superb long-lasting stability and splendid ability to detect NACs even at ppb level. In addition to NACs, the reduction of NOX has been investigated by different PBA-based catalysts. The reduction of NOx to nitrogen gas is usually accomplished via selective catalytic reaction (SCR) using ammonia as the reducing compound (Eq. (38)) [137,138]. Vanadium-based catalysts have been used extensively to accelerate the reduction reaction of NOX [139–141]. However, the toxicity and limited temperature range are among the drawbacks of these catalysts [142]. (38) 4 N O + 4 N H 3 + O 2 → 4 N 2 + 6 H 2 O On the other hand, transition metals-based catalysts have overcome the issues of V-based catalysts. Regarding this, PBA as the precursor for transition metals have been investigated for the preparation of catalysts. In terms of the physical properties of the catalyst, the porosity of the catalyst plays a key role in providing the channels for adsorption of molecules and electron transfer [143–146]. A hollow catalyst can adsorb more NH3 and NOX on its surface and, as a result, more reduction would be achieved. Moreover, catalysts with smaller cubic structures seem to possess bigger pore sizes thus enhancing the mass transfer and heat diffusion [124]. However, it should be noted that the scale of the cubic structure must be optimized since in very small structures the alkaline ion (Na, K, Li) can block active sites and consequently decrease the catalytic activity. In addition to physical properties, the chemical properties of the catalysts are of concern. Yan et al. [147] reported that when the scale of the cubic structure decreased, the content of transition metals like Mn4+ and Fe3+ and reactive species on the surface of the catalyst would be higher. The results form Kirkendall effect showed that by decreasing the scale of the catalyst, cations would come closer or move to each other's lattice thus enhancing the synergistic effect between metal cations. Reduction of H2O2 is another catalytic application for PB-based catalysts. Hydrogen peroxide is a product of biological reactions and has been widely used in the industry and for pollution control. Therefore, its detection is essential to increase the knowledge on safety guidelines and the associated environmental hazards. One of the determination procedures for hydrogen peroxide is the electrochemical method which is based on the electrochemistry of peroxidase [148]. However, the electrochemical detection requires a high overpotential. Thus, a mediator is needed [149]. Due to the similarity of PB to peroxidase and its good electrochemical conductivity, it has been deployed as a mediator in biosensing applications for the reduction of H2O2 [150]. Studies showed that the high-spin and low-spin iron ions provide a channel for electron transfer that helps in the reduction of hydrogen peroxide [151,152]. 3.5 Water splitting Hydrogen gas is considered as a sustainable alternative for fossil fuels. Water splitting is a technique that has been extensively utilized in order to produce green energy via decomposition of water into hydrogen and oxygen gas [153,154]. Water splitting involves two half reactions called hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Depending on the pH level, the HER and OER will be different in acidic Eq. (39) and ((40)) and neutral or basic conditions Eq. (41) and ((42)) as mentioned hereunder [155,156]. Acidic condition: (39) HER : 2 H + + 2 e − → H 2 (40) OER : H 2 O → 2 H + + 1 / 2 O 2 + 2 e − Neutral and alkaline condition: (41) HER : 2 H 2 O + 2 e − → H 2 + 2 O H − (42) OER : 2 O H − → 2 H + + 1 / 2 O 2 + 2 e − It is worth mentioning that this process has very slow kinetics which prevents the exploitation of this approach from being practical. However, catalysts can accelerate the course. Previously, noble metals like palladium have been used as catalysts for water splitting. Due to their higher costs, alternative catalysts derived from transition metals have now been investigated [157–159]. Since PBA can be made of different transition metals like Ni, Fe, and Co, it has been utilized as the precursor for the preparation of the electrocatalysts. The OER and HER performance of some PBA-based catalysts are presented in Tables 4 and 5 , respectively. One advantage that makes PBA a favorable precursor for catalysts preparation is its porous structure which facilitates the mass transfer and diffusion of ions leading to an increase in active sites and as a result faster kinetics [160,161]. In addition, as it has high surface area it can accommodate more unsaturated sites expediating the absorption of reactants [162]. Besides, PBA can be modified to operate in both HER and OER. Introduction of different materials into PBA can change its structure to amorphous one. Since amorphous materials have higher bonds randomly oriented on their surface, they can provide more active sites thus enhancing the adsorption and desorption of reactants [163,164]. Furthermore, these structures can boost charge transfer due to oxygen vacancies [165]. It has been reported that nickel ions in amorphous structure displayed higher reactivity due to their enhanced oxidation to a higher valance state [166]. Introduction of different transition metals into PBA may lead to a synergistic effect [167]. Moreover, PBA has been explored as the template to synthesize metal sulfides, oxides, selenides, phosphides, and carbon alloys [168–171]; phosphidation reportedly plays a crucial role on the catalytic activity of PBA. Xuan et al. [172] revealed that presence of Ni, Fe, and P atoms can promote electron transfer leading to higher OER and HER rate; introduction of nickel and phosphorous, particularly nickel, enhanced the HER activity as it could facilitate electron transfer due to lower charge-transfer resistance thus increasing the catalytic activity in OER and HER. It was reported that metal phosphides are more efficient than metal oxides since the electronic structure is more optimized and as a result the conductivity of metal phosphides are higher leading to enhanced charge transfer. Since phosphorous has high electronegativity, it can promote protons capture. This feature in HER leads to a better hydrogen delivery. In another study, Ma et al. [173] investigated the catalytic performance of Fe3O4/CuO composite in water oxidation using sodium persulfate; the composite was synthesized using Cu-Fe PBA as a precursor. The catalysts showed excellent catalytic performance in water oxidation process and the plausible mechanism for OER process illustrated in Fig. 18 . Since the synthesized composite is hydroxylated, when sodium persulfate was added to the solution, sulfate radicals were generated due to the electron transfer between copper and persulfate. Consequently, oxygen anions were generated. Moreover, peroxygen was produced due to the interaction of copper and sulfate radicals in presence of water. In the next step, peroxy anions were produced as a result of hydroxide and peroxygen bond, followed by OER. Cu(III) played a key role in the evolution of oxygen. In addition, the iron species on the surface of the catalyst performed as Fenton reagents and reduced Cu(III) to Cu(II) resulting in the generation of free radicals. Muthurasu et al. [174] revealed that metal oxide and hydroxide were produced during the water splitting reaction using Co-Fe-P catalyst. The metal oxide produced during the reaction provided active sites for OER and the phosphate could be produced on the surface of the catalyst which acted as a charge transport mediator. The catalytic reactions during OER are described in Eq. (43)–(47), where CAT represents the catalysts. (43) C A T + O H − → C A T − O H + e − (44) C A T − O H → C A T − O + H 2 O (45) C A T − O + O H − → C A T − O O H + e − (46) C A T − O O H + O H − → C A T − O 2 + H 2 O + e − (47) C A T − O 2 → C A T + O 2 The above reactions are the adsorption steps on the surface of the catalysts where the metal cations on the surface of the catalyst are electrophile increasing the adsorption of oxygen. This phenomenon could facilitate the reaction of OH and consequently the catalytic activity in OER. On the other hand, in HER, the hydrogen production was facilitated by multistep reactions based on Volmer (Eq. (48)), Heyrovsky (Eq. (49)), and Tafel (Eq. (50)) reactions. It is noteworthy that Volmer and Heyrovsky reactions represent the electrochemical hydrogen adsorption on the catalyst's surface in alkaline condition while Tafel corresponds to desorption. Based on Sabatier principle, the catalyst surface should create a strong bond to keep the hydrogen on its surface meanwhile the bond should be cleaved easily to generate H2 gas. In view of this, the metal phosphide could facilitate the charge transfer and promote the free energy of intermediate species which were critical for the adsorption and desorption kinetics. Furthermore, the most common active sites on the surface of the catalysts are -OH, =O, -O-O-H. It has been reported that the number of defects indicating the surface oxygen vacancies are important in catalytic activity because they can ameliorate the conductivity and expediate the kinetics of redox reactions. (48) H 2 O + C A T + e − → C A T − H + O H − (49) CAT − H + H 2 O + e − → CAT + O H − + H 2 (50) 2 CAT − H → 2 CAT + H 2 Selenization or selenylation is another promising way to increase the electrocatalytic activity of PBA-based composites. It has been reported that this process helped the transfer of electron and proton and the delivery of dioxygen molecules [175–177]. Zhang et al. [178] prepared a (Fe-Co) Se2 composite using PBA as the template which could deliver a high performance in OER and HER due to the synergistic effect of iron and cobalt atoms along with selenization. The composite also had small charge-transfer resistance indicating its fast electron transfer capability. Incorporation of carbon into the PBA-based catalysts also boosts the catalytic activity of PBA since graphitization of PBA can protect the catalyst from corrosion while preventing the aggregation. Carbon is usually doped with nitrogen to change the charge distribution leading to the facilitated electron transfer, especially in OER [179]. Different forms of carbon materials including nanofibers, nanotubes, and carbon cloth have been assessed to synthesis an electrochemical catalyst [180]. Studies revealed that the porous structure of carbon-PBA composite facilitated the electron transport, mass transfer, and adsorption of intermediates in OER and oxygen reduction reactions (ORR) [180,181]. In addition, the presence of N on the carbon surface improves the synergistic effect and provides more active sites needed for better performance [182]. 3.6 Electrochemical energy storage As discussed in water splitting section 3.5, alternative means to avoid overconsumption of fossil fuels has been investigated. Recently, electrochemical energy storage has been assessed on large-scale, ranging from portable electronic devices to electric cars. Charge storage mechanisms on the electrode's surface, including surface accumulation (like supercapacitors) and intercalation of metal ions (like metal-ion batteries), offer the basis for functioning of electric devices; the chemistry of electrodes affects the performance of electronics. The ideal electrode surface should have sufficient active sites to provide efficient storage and electrocatalytic reaction besides good electrical conductivity, high surface area, and pore sizes [183,184]. As mentioned above, PB and its analogues are the materials that possess these characteristics as the application of PB and PBAs in electrochemical energy storage has been investigated [185] including deployment in mono-valent metal-ion batteries, multi-valent metal-ion batteries, and supercapacitors. Redox reactions at PB and PBAs metal centers have been considered to occur frequently in energy storage applications [186]. Additionally, the lattice water content in PB/PBAs, ionic radius, charge number, and solvation energy were found to be influential in the energy storage performance of PB/PBAs-based batteries. For instance, Sottmann et al. [187] revealed that high lattice water content and Fe (CN)6 vacancy decreased the performance of sodium-ion batteries. In another study, Wu et al. [188] studied the effect of lattice defects on the performance of lithium-ion batteries by synthesizing Fe-Fe nanomaterials with controlled defects; lattice defects and water content limited redox reactions in the cathode resulting in poor stability. PB and PBAs have also been evaluated in Li-ion batteries as anode material where they exhibited low Li storage capacity while displaying excellent properties [184]. Therefore, more investigations are needed to improve the conductivity of anode materials fabricated from PB-based materials. Crystallite size has been found to be effective on the storage capability of potassium-based batteries made from PBA; He and Nazar 2017 [189] reported that the increase in particle size gradually decreased the capacity of K-ion batteries. The framework of PB/PBAs was reported to be beneficial in diffusing sodium ions which can enhance the charge storage capacity of Na-ion batteries [190,191] besides being effective on the intercalation and deintercalation of metal ions, especially in Mg-ion batteries [192,193]. Other than Mg-ion, Ca-ion, Zn-ion, and Al-ion batteries using PBA cathodes have been investigated in several studies, and the results have been promising [194–197] though additional studies are required to improve their performance. For example, PBA cathodes could be poisoned by Zn ions and aluminum-ion batteries lack suitable electrolyte that needs further explorations. In addition to batteries, several studies have investigated PB/PBAs as supercapacitors where their metal centers play a key role in providing active sites for Faradaic reactions enhancing storage capacity. To provide better conductivity, some studies have examined the combination of carbon materials with PB/PBAs [198,199]. For example, Wang et al. [198] studied PB/graphene composite, which was more efficient than pristine PB. In addition to carbonaceous materials, polymers have been added to PB/PBA structure to enhance their conductivity [200]. Also, the morphology of PB/PBA nanocrystals was found to be effective as hollow PBA shells could accelerate mass transfer resulting in higher capacitance [201]. In addition to morphology, lattice defects have been studied; Zhao et al. [202] reported that lattice defects in PBA structure increased porosity resulting in superior transport of metallic ions. 3.7 Miscellaneous applications There are some additional studies that have been evaluating the catalytic performance of PB-based catalysts in different applications in the recent years, although the literature is rather limited. The other catalytic applications of PB include the epoxidation of styrene, combustion, aerobic oxidation and A3 coupling reactions. Styrene oxide is a key organic chemical that is widely used in the chemical and pharmaceutical industry and often obtained by epoxidation of styrene [203]. However, the conventional synthesis methods are found to be corrosive and toxic for equipment and the environment [204,205]. Recently, double metal cyanide (DMC) catalysts including PBA have been investigated in the epoxidation of styrene. It is noteworthy that the type of solvent used in the process may affect the efficacy. For example, Liang et al. [206] revealed that the Cu-Co PBA in aprotic solvents had better performance than protic ones. Incorporation of other metals has also been investigated as illustrated by Guo et al. [207] that the addition of Cs into the Fe-Co PBA could distort the crystallinity of the original catalyst producing more surface area and active sites for the mass transfer in the epoxidation process. Besides the addition of metals and higher surface area, acid sites are crucial for an efficient catalyst. In a recent study, Guo et al. [208] reported that the presence of acid sites on the surface of the catalyst can improve the catalytic activity as they prepared trimetallic PBAs by introducing Fe and Cu into Fe-Co, Cd-Co, Co-Co, Mn-Co, and Zn-Co PBAs. The NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) test showed that addition of Zn could reduce the acidity of the catalysts leading to poor activity. Additionally, the incorporation of a third metal could significantly improve the catalytic performance especially copper, since its selectivity and reactivity for styrene oxide is high. The results indicated that the N-coordinated metals performed as active sites in comparison with C-coordinated metals. Catalytic combustion of gases specifically chlorinated volatile organic compounds (CVOCs) has been recently investigated [209,210]. However, due to chlorine poisoning resulting in low stability of active sites, transition metals catalysts do not have high efficiency [211]. In this context, Zhao et al. [212] developed a chainmail catalyst of Co-Mn PBA coated with a TiO2 shell with double-wall nanocage morphology to investigate its catalytic performance in combustion of o-dichlorobenzene. The coating of TiO2 shell on the catalyst surface noticeably enhanced the catalytic activity because the shell could protect the PBA from deactivation (the loss of Mn and reduction of Co3+ to Co2+) and the adsorption of chlorine species. However, the thickness of the TiO2 need to be optimized since thin or thick layer could decrease the catalytic activity. In addition, encapsulating the catalyst with TiO2 enhanced the surface area, surface lattice oxygen and active adsorbed oxygen resulting in better catalytic performance as oxygen groups played a critical role in the catalytic destruction of CVOCs. It is worth noting that abundant acid sites could decrease the apparent activation energy of the catalyst causing improved activity. Marquez et al. [213] investigated the catalytic activity of trimetallic PBA in A3 coupling reaction of phenylacetylene, benzaldehyde, and piperidine via the incorporation of Cu (II) into Zn-Co PBA; trimetallic catalyst had the higher selectivity towards A3 coupling by-products. The Cu (II) significantly increased the performance of the catalyst since it could cause the generation of metal acetylide that accelerates the activation of phenylacetylene. Furthermore, A3 products could be increased due to the presence of Zn2+ that helps the formation of iminium ion intermediate. In addition, the coupling reaction between iminium ion and the metal acetylide would be facilitated by zinc atoms, enhanced selectivity for A3 products is another attribute of zinc. The authors studied the basic function of PBA and found that the superb performance of the catalyst could be attributed to the presence of C H 3 CO O − in the PBA. Previously, it has been reported that acetate ion can provide basicity thus improving the C-H activation of phenylacetylene due to the generation of metal acetylide. Moreover, the basic function added to the PBA could enhance the Henry reaction (nitroaldol reaction) since this reaction needs a base to proceed. In view of this, the PBA exhibited a great basicity in the A3 coupling reaction. Recently oxidation of lignin to produce valuable chemicals has been investigated using different methods [214,215]. Heterogeneous catalytic oxidation of vanillyl alcohol (VAL) as a lignin model compound to vanillin has become attractive to researchers since vanillin (VN) is a valuable product consumed by several industries [216]. Zheng et al. [217] evaluated the catalytic activity of various Fe- and Co-based PBAs with different transition metals including Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn in the aerobic oxidation of VAL. The results indicated that Fe-Fe PBA had the highest efficiency with conversion rate (consumed VAL/total VAL) of 70%, yield (VN produced/VAL consumed) of 31%, and selectivity (VN produced/ total products) of 91%. The higher efficiency of the catalyst was attributed to the high acidity and redox properties of iron ions. 4 Conclusions The overarching aim of this review is to provide a comprehensive overview of the catalytic applications of PB and its analogous that are known by another name as metal hexacyanoferrates. PBA, as a metal organic framework, has recently garnered tremendous attention due to its unique structural and chemical properties making it an entity with a wide range of applications including catalysis, energy storage, sensors, and medicine. The catalytic applications of PB and its analogous comprise advanced oxidation processes (AOPs), reduction reactions, and water splitting besides an array of miscellaneous catalytic applications [252-256]. PBA-based catalysts have been recently used in AOPs like persulfate activation, Fenton-based reactions and photocatalytic degradation processes. In all AOPs, PBAs have been used as the template for synthesis of catalysts and sources for transition metals that have pronounced catalytic effect. It was revealed that changes in morphology, addition of heteroatoms like nitrogen, incorporation of carbonaceous materials or noble metals could affect the catalytic activity of PBA-based catalysts. In reduction reactions, synergistic effect of bimetallic catalyst showed a greater efficiency. Like AOPs, introduction of heteroatoms and noble metals like Pd could increase active sites and electron transfer for the reduction of pollutants such as nitroaromatics and NOX. Water splitting is another realm of catalytic performance for PBA-based composites as numerous researchers have strived to develop catalyst that could be utilized in OER and HER reaction simultaneously. Phosphidation and selenization of catalyst were reported to be effective in overall water splitting performance. Epoxidation of styrene, catalytic combustion, A3 coupling reactions, and the oxidation of vanillyl alcohol are other catalytic applications of PBA-based catalysts that need further investigations since the literature lacks sufficient knowledge base in these segments. However, notable studies have surmised that incorporation of a third metal into bimetallic catalysts significantly increases the catalytic performance. Finally, the authors have endeavored to compile a reference document for the catalytic applications of PB and its analogous to help assist researchers to dive deep into the chemistry and catalytic role of hexacyanoferrates in diverse applications. There are still several knowledge gaps in the detailed underlying mechanisms for these catalytic reactions involved in the aforementioned processes. In addition, all the research papers on this topic have been restricted to the lab-scale that accentuates the importance of pilot-scale and field studies to investigate the effect of environmental parameters on the catalytic performance of PBA-based catalysts. Finally, since there are different synthesis methods known for the PBA-based composites, environmentally-friendly and greener synthetic strategies including the use of alternate activation methods such as microwave, ultrasound, mechanochemical, especially in continuous mode, need to be further investigated. coredata.dc:description: Environmental issues pertaining to global warming and pollution have become a global concern and solutions are, therefore, being urgently sought with a wide ranging application of suitable entity to minimize the energy consumption while curbing associated economic costs. Prussian blue (PB) ( Fe 4 3 + [ F e 2 + ( CN ) 6 ] 3 ) and its PB analogous (PBA) ( A 2 T [ M ( CN ) 6 ] , A=Li, K, Na; T=Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, Cu, etc.; M=Fe, Mn, Co, etc.) are metal organic frameworks that have numerous appliances and have garnered major attention in recent years. However, there are only handful of reviews discussing the fundamental catalytic properties of PB-based materials and hence this effort to comprehensively review and systematically discuss the critical role of PB-based materials in broader catalytic context embracing environment and the energy aspects. Initially, the fundamentals and principles of underlying processes are elucidated followed by a detailed discussion on the catalytic performance and applications of PBA-based catalysts in advanced oxidation processes, reduction reactions, water splitting, and miscellaneous applications, among others. This comprehensive overview features details of the broad catalytic activities of PBA-based materials in diverse applications and hopefully would be a reference on PBA-centered catalysts in an array of applications including industrial applications.
coredata.dc:title: Prussian blue-based nanostructured materials: Catalytic applications for environmental remediation and energy conversion
